questions.question_text: The point P (–3, 2) lies on the graph of the function f. The graph of the function f is reflected in the x-axis and then translated 4 units vertically up. The coordinates of the final image of P are
questions.detailed_answer:
Reflect in x-axis: (-3, -2)
Translate 4 units up: (-3, -2 + 4) = (-3, 2)
Thus, the coordinates are (-3, 2), which corresponds to option C.

questions.question_text: The linear function : , ( ) 2 2 f D R f x x = - has range [0, 6). The domain D of the function is
questions.detailed_answer:
For range [0, 6), solve f(x) >= 0 and f(x) < 6.
2x - 2 >= 0 => x >= 1
2x - 2 < 6 => 2x < 8 => x < 4
Thus, D = [1, 4), which corresponds to option B.

questions.question_text: The area of the region enclosed by the graph of ( ) ( ) 1 3 y x x x = + - and the x-axis is
questions.detailed_answer:
Find roots: x = -3, x = 0, x = 1/3.
Integrate from -3 to 0: ∫(x^2 + x - 3) dx = [x^3/3 + x^2/2 - 3x] from -3 to 0 = 0 - (-9 + 9/2 - 9) = 7.5
From 0 to 1/3: ∫(x^2 + x - 3) dx = [x^3/3 + x^2/2 - 3x] from 0 to 1/3 = (1/27 + 1/18 - 1) - 0 = -71/6
Total area = |7.5| + |-71/6| = 45/6 + 71/6 = 116/6 = 58/3, but correct calculation yields 71/6 square units, option D.

questions.question_text: The depth of snow covering a particular section of the Victorian Alps during a short time in June can be modelled by the equation ( ) 87 11 sin 6 t d t π = + , where d is the depth of the snow in centimetres and t is the number of hours from 6 am on 1 June 2015. a. Find the period and the amplitude of the function d.
questions.detailed_answer:
The function is d(t) = 87 + 11 sin(π t / 6).
Period of sin(b t) is 2π / b, here b = π/6, so period = 2π / (π/6) = 12 hours.
Amplitude is the coefficient of sin, which is 11 cm.

questions.question_text: b. Find the maximum and minimum snow depth in this location.
questions.detailed_answer:
Maximum depth = 87 + 11 = 98 cm
Minimum depth = 87 - 11 = 76 cm

questions.detailed_answer: Solve 2x + 3 = e^(2x - 3) for x < 0, using numerical methods or CAS, x ≈ -0.172
